utterances: Good.

Pretty good.
Okay.
I am a stay-at-home mom of four and I started out my life being a single mom.
So to me, it meant a whole lot to not have all that extra stuff.
And one of the things that we started doing in the last two years was we ask for no more toys for birthdays.
We asked for markers and paper and crayon and modeling clay and books.
And that's all we got, because otherwise, when my kids get those toys that they see on TV, they sit in the corner and they get ruined and pieces get lost.
And the playroom gets trashed and nobody is creative and nobody's having fun.
I think you may have formed your own marketing department.

It was - it's been great now that we've scaled back on toys and all those other things.
They play outside more.

Right.

Well, you know, I think that what businesses have done is they've really - it's very smart.
They have come up for, you know, something to address every parents', any parents', you know, possible momentary worry, anxiety, fear, twinge, desire, you know, hope for their children.
If you have, you know, a 4-month-old who isn't sitting up properly, there are about five different, you know, baby seat, you know, sitting encourager, sort of, seats that you can buy…
Mm-hmm.
…to put your kid in to help them sit upright.
And a lot of this is motivated by fear, isn't it?
Absolutely.
You know, I think that underlying - I mean, there are a lot of social and cultural reasons why this is happening now.
And I go into that in the book.
But, you know, some of it is, I think, an underlying economic insecurity.
I think that this generation of parents really feels like they are not going to be able to necessarily provide for their children in the way that their own parents did for them.
And there's a fear that the world has grown increasingly competitive that jobs are unstable, that getting into college is impossible.
And, you know, parents want to help.
College, preschool - getting into preschool is impossible.
